facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 15th May 1970 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 737 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 15th May, 1970 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 737 of 1968.

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 15 of 1971 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 15th May, 1970 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 737 of 1968. Frank Anthony and K. B. Rohatgi, for the appellant.

facts.text: Accused appellant was Assistant Station Master at Ateli in May 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The accused  appellant  was an Assistant Station Master at Ateli in May 1967. P.W. 3, a member of the Armed Forces, was going back home by train from Udaipur with his wife and child on railway concession pass, carrying with him a trunk and bedding.

facts.text: P.W. 3, member of Armed Forces, traveling from Udaipur to home by train with wife and child on railway concession pass, carrying trunk and bedding.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3, a member of the Armed Forces, was going back home by train from Udaipur with his wife and child on railway concession pass, carrying with him a trunk and bedding. When the, train reached Ateli Railway station in the afternoon of May 9, 1967, P.W. 3 got down with his baggage and, when he handed over his ticket to the accused, was told that he had to pay extra for his wife and child and excess luggage--a sum around Rs. 45 or more.

facts.text: Train reached Ateli Railway station in the afternoon of May 9, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: When the, train reached Ateli Railway station in the afternoon of May 9, 1967, P.W. 3 got down with his baggage and, when he handed over his ticket to the accused, was told that he had to pay extra for his wife and child and excess luggage--a sum around Rs. 45 or more.

facts.text: P.W. 3 handed ticket to accused and was told to pay extra Rs. 45 or more for wife, child and excess luggage.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3 got down with his baggage and, when he handed over his ticket to the accused, was told that he had to pay extra for his wife and child and excess luggage--a sum around Rs. 45 or more. W. 3 pleaded that he had numbermoney on him then and was suggested a way out by the payment of Rs. 10 at once a bribe and a bargain.

facts.text: P.W. 3 had no money, paid Rs. 10 as bribe, promised to bring more next day, left bedding as hostage.

anchor.surface_text: W. 3 pleaded that he had numbermoney on him then and was suggested a way out by the payment of Rs. 10 at once a bribe and a bargain. Promising to bring the money the next day, W. 3 left the station leaving his bedding as something of a number-human hostage which was to be released on the payment of the illicit sum.

facts.text: P.W. 3 informed Deputy Commissioner Narnaul on May 11 about the incident.

anchor.surface_text: On reaching his village late in the night, P.W. 3, the Jawan, thought of informing the authorities about this harassment. Accordingly, he companytacted the Deputy Commissioner, Narnaul, on May 11 and related to him what had happened.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner instructed Superintendent of Police, who directed Deputy Superintendent of Police Narnaul to take action.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner instructed the Superintendent of Police to look into the matter who directed the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Narnaul, to take suitable action. He also sent a telephonic message to Shri Dharamvir, Sub Divisional Magistrate, Narnaul, and told him that Sis Ram had been directed to companytact the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Narnaul, in companynection with his companyplaint.

facts.text: Sub Divisional Magistrate P.W. 5 and Deputy Superintendent of Police organized trap after apprised by P.W. 3.

anchor.surface_text: thereupon, the Sub Divisional Magistrate, P.W. 5, together with the Deputy Superintendent of Police, decided to organise a trap, on being apprised of the story by P.W. 3. The team companysisted of the Deputy Superintendent, the Sub Divisional Magistrate, a head companystable of the railway police, and P.W. 3 himself.

facts.text: Trap team consisted of Deputy Superintendent, Sub Divisional Magistrate, head constable of railway police, P.W. 3, and P.W. 4 Lakshmi Narain joined.

anchor.surface_text: The team companysisted of the Deputy Superintendent, the Sub Divisional Magistrate, a head companystable of the railway police, and P.W. 3 himself. The party moved to the railway station and P.W. 4, Lakshmi Narain, also joined them on the way.

facts.text: Ten-rupee note Ex. P1 handed by P.W.3 to Sub Divisional Magistrate, who signed it, memo Ex. PF prepared.

anchor.surface_text: A ten-rupee numbere  Ex. PI  was handed over by P.W.3 to the Sub Divisional Magistrate, who signed on it,.in token whereof a memo was prepared, Ex. PF. P.W. 3 took back the numbere, his body was searched as part of the usual precaution and he was directed to go to the accused and give signal after the money was paid.

facts.text: P.W. 3 met accused, gave marked money, gave signal, party closed in, marked note recovered from accused's right hand vide memo Ex. PG.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3 took back the numbere, his body was searched as part of the usual precaution and he was directed to go to the accused and give signal after the money was paid. As arranged, P.W. 3 met the accused, made over the money, gave a signal whereupon the party of the Sub Divisional Magistrate closed in on the accused. The marked numbere was recovered from his right hand  vide memo. Ex. PG .

facts.text: Sub Divisional Magistrate lodged First Information Report, case registered, investigation by Deputy Superintendent of Police Railways P.W. 7.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Sub Divisional Magistrate lodged a First Information Report with the police, a case was registered and on companypletion of investigation by the Deputy Superintendent of Police having jurisdiction over the Railways, P.W. 7, and after obtaining the statutory sanction, Ex. PD/1, the accused was charged with an offence of having accepted illegal gratification of Rs. 10 on May 11, 1967 from P.W. 3 thereby companymitting criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duties, punishable under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

facts.text: Statutory sanction Ex. PD/1 obtained.

anchor.surface_text: ...and after obtaining the statutory sanction, Ex. PD/1,...

facts.text: Accused charged with accepting illegal gratification of Rs. 10 on May 11, 1967 from P.W. 3 under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: ...the accused was charged with an offence of having accepted illegal gratification of Rs. 10 on May 11, 1967 from P.W. 3 thereby companymitting criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duties, punishable under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

facts.text: Special Judge convicted the accused, overruling defence under s.342 Cr.P.C., disbelieving defence witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge companyvicted the accused, overruling the defence version set up under s. 342, Cr. P.C., and disbelieving the defence witnesses. The High Court companyfirmed the companyviction.

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction and sentence of one year RI and Rs.200 fine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyfirmed the companyviction. The sentence of one year rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 200 was also companyfirmed.

facts.text: P.W. 2, Divisional Operating Superintendent Western Railway Udaipur, granted sanction Ex. PD/1, competent by delegated powers to remove Assistant Station Master.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Frank Anthony sought to make good his companytention regarding the invalidity of the sanction, Ex. PD/1, by urging that P.W. 2, a Divisional Officer  Senior Scale , who granted the sanction did number and, under the rules, companyld number appoint or dismiss the accused. It has to be mentioned right at the beginning that P.W. 2, who was working as Divisional Operating Superintendent, Western Railway, Udaipur, has sworn that by virtue of delegated powers he was companypetent to remove an Assistant Station Master like the accused.

facts.text: Defence version: Jawan stopped by attender at gate for insufficient tickets and excess baggage, accused allowed after check, reported to Jaipur Station Master, bedding left in lost property room.

anchor.surface_text: The companynter- story of the Assistant Station Master  accused  was that the Jawan was stopped by the attender  or water carrier  of the station at the gate for insufficient  tickets and excess baggage but, after some sound and fury over an interpolation in the military pass, was allowed to go by the accused who promptly reported to the Jaipur Station Master to know how many passengers were companyered by the pass. The inconvenient bedding of the Jawan was explained by the accused as having been left behind by P.W. 3 in the heat of the moment and had been kept in the lost property room and entered in the relevant register.

facts.text: Courts below rejected accused's exculpatory case.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrts below have rejected this exculpatory case of the appellant and we see numberhing too odd in the appreciation or too unnatural in the inference to warrant our interference.

facts.text: P.W. 1, fellow station master, supported accused but disbelieved.

anchor.surface_text: True, P.W. 1, the fellow station master, has endeavoured to substantiate the appellants plea but has been disbelieved. After all, the successful and sustained prevalence of rackets .Eke companyruption is built on the artful network of sharing agencies and the rescue operations of P.W. 1 cannot be regarded as independent evidence of an unconnected officer.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, confirmed conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we find numberreason for interfering with the companycurrent companyviction and sentence. The appeal is dismissed.

arguments.claim: s5A not violated as trap not investigation; done by competent DSP PW7

anchor.surface_text: The mandate of s. 5A is merely that no police officer below the rank of a Deputy Superintendent of Police shall investigate any of the offences specified there. Here, no investigation was done by a lesser police officer, for P.W. 7, who did the investigation, was of competent rank and what the Magistrate, P.W. 5, did was not investigation and was de hors S. 5A.

arguments.claim: trap evidence reliable if corroborated; magistrate participation ok

anchor.surface_text: Two decisions were pressed before us by Shri Frank Anthony. The first, Vinayak V. Joshi v. State 1 , is easily distinguishable. There, a Divisional Medical Officer who was of equal status with a Divisional Personnel Officer granted sanction but he had numberdelegation of powers of appointment which only the latter enjoyed.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in S. 5A preventing an executive magistrate or other public officer laying a trap to catch an allegedly companyrupt official. The ruling in State of Bihar v. Basawan Singh  2   by implication upholds this position.
